title: Interstitial redirect bypass / open redirect in https://hackerone.com/zendesk_session

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi guys , I have found a way to use the open redirect vulnerability that zendesk refused to fix and we discussed it in #101146 to bypass intristial redirect. 
in #101146 , @bencode said : 
> I tend to agree with Zendesk, we don't really see any security issues with it. We use our interstitial to warn the user and it's clear you are on a separate site.

Well , using this issue I could bypass the interstitial redirect.
#PoC:
[Clicking here will bypass interistial redirect and get you on evil.com](https://hackerone.com/zendesk_session?locale_id=1&return_to=https://support.hackerone.com/ping/redirect_to_account?state=compayn:/)
 
The link is `https://hackerone.com/zendesk_session?locale_id=1&return_to=https://support.hackerone.com/ping/redirect_to_account?state=compayn:/` which is used to redirect to generate a zendesk session.
This can be fixed from your end , by detecting the `/ping/redirect_to_account` in the `return_to` parameter. 
Thanks

activities.message:
The evil.com is coming from the zendesk account that I created "compayn.zendesk.com" , I added :
```html
<script>document.location.href = "http://evil.com"; </script>
```
 To the header file through my zendesk theme editor.
The problem with zendesk is that they allow redirecting from one account to another through the endpoint `/ping/redirect_to_account`  which makes an attacker able to use his zendesk account as an open redirector and in your case , I am able to achieve open redirect through HackerOne.com . 
I have already reported this issue to zendesk but they decided not to fix it and closed the report as N/A :P

activities.message:
Hi @mvgijssel , you have mistakenly informed me through #111192 that this issue was fixed , however, I have managed to bypass your fix.
[Clicking here will get you on evil.com](/zendesk_session?locale_id=1&return_to=https://support.hackerone.com/ping/redirect_to_account?state=compayn:/ )
Markdown:
```
[Clicking here will get you on evil.com](/zendesk_session?locale_id=1&return_to=https://support.hackerone.com/ping/redirect_to_account?state=compayn:/)
```
The fix you produced only prevents the interstitial bypass in reports , but the endpoint `https://hackerone.com/zendesk_session` is still vulnerable to open redirect due to the fact that zendesk allows redirecting to other zendesk accounts.
So , I guess fixing the open redirect issue in `/zendesk_session` will also address the redirect filter bypass issue.

Thanks.

The endpoint `/zendesk_session` is still vulnerable to open redirect and I still can use this to bypass the redirect filter.

Hey @zombiehelp54,

Just to be clear, the fix we are talking about is it to parse the `return_to` URL and remove or limit the `state` parameter. We did consider this fix and are still talking about it. Our main problems is that it is brittle because we don't have control over it and don't understand all the parameters that are being used. Do you have any thoughts or suggestions?

Thanks,
@bencode

summaries.content:
Links with `hackerone.com` domain were treated as trusted links, including those followed by `/zendesk_session`. Anyone can create a custom Zendesk account that redirects to an untrusted website and provide it in `/redirect_to_account?state=` param; and because Zendesk allows redirecting between accounts without interstitial, you'd be taken to the untrusted site without any warning. 

Given that the origin of the issue is within Zendesk, we've chosen to identify the links with `zendesk_session` as external links which would render an external icon and an interstitial warning page when clicked.
summaries.content_html:
Links with hackerone.com domain were treated as trusted links, including those followed by /zendesk_session. Anyone can create a custom Zendesk account that redirects to an untrusted website and provide it in /redirect_to_account?state= param; and because Zendesk allows redirecting between accounts without interstitial, you'd be taken to the untrusted site without any warning.

Given that the origin of the issue is within Zendesk, we've chosen to identify the links with zendesk_session as external links which would render an external icon and an interstitial warning page when clicked.
